speaker: Hon. J. C. Moore. 34 Mr Hurford
theText: The answer to the honourableall Government programs and services. My Department (2) When was each of the current Divisions created is currently analysing reports from other portfolio areas and from which previous Division was each created. on measures already implemented and being planned to (3) Is this information available in booklet form; if achieve these goals. I shall report to Parliament on the not, will he instruct the Australian Electoral Commisresults of this exercise at the first opportunity. sion to prepare and publish the information in booklet form. (Question No. 2176) member's question is as follows: Mr Leo McLeay asked the Special Minister The Electoral Commissioner has advised: of State, upon notice, on 11 October 1985: (1) Electoral Divisions-Origins of names as set out in the Report of the House of Representatives Select (I) What is the origin of the name of each federal Committee on the Naming of Electoral Divisions (the Electoral Division. Fox Report) with later additions. Adelaide (SA) . Locality name-city named after consort of William IV. Aston (Vic). Tilly Aston-blind writer and teacher, helped found library of Victorian Association of Braille writers. Ballarat (Vic) Locality-name derived from two Aboriginal words meanings 'Leaning on elbow'. Banks (NSW) . Sir Joseph Banks-botanist with Captain James Cook. Barker (SA) Collet Barker who in 1831 was sent by Governor Darling of New South Wales to try to solve the mystery of the mouth of the River Murray. Barton (NSW). Sir Edmund Barton-Australia's first Prime Minister. Bass (Tas) . George Bass-explorer. Batman (Vic) . John Batman-settler and explorer. Bendigo (Vic) . Locality-originated from name of an English prize fighter. Bennelong (NSW) Name of Aboriginal whom GoVernor Arthur Phillip befriended in 1788. Berowra (NSW) Geographical. Blaxland (NSW) John Blaxland-explorer. Bonython (SA) Sir John Langdon Bonython-elected to the first House of Representatives to represent South Australia in 1901, and in 1903 elected as the first member for the Division of Barker. Boothby (SA). . . William Robert Boothby-the Returning Officer for the first election of Members Of the House of Representatives in 1901; in 1903 appointed' as Commissioner to distribute South Australia into seven Electoral Divisions. Bowman (Qld) David Bowman-Member of the Queensland Parliament 1899-1916, Leader of the Opposition and then Home Secretary. Braddon (Tas). Sir Edward Nicholas Coventry Braddon-a member of Tasmanian House of Assembly 1879-1888 and 1893-1901; Member of the House of Representatives 1901-1903. Bradfield (NSW) . John Job Crew Bradfield-engineer and bridge designer. Brand (WA) . Sir David Brand-Premier of Western Australia 1959-71. Brisbane (Qld). . Locality name-after Sir Thomas Makdougall Brisbane, Governor of New South Wales from 1820 to 1825. The Penal Colony at Moreton Bay was established by John Oxley and with the Governor's permission the settlement was named Brisbane. Bruce (Vic). . Standley Melbourne (later Lord) Bruce-former Prime Minister. Burke (Vic). Robert Burke-explorer. Calare (NSW). Aboriginal name for Lachlan River. Cal well (Vic) . Arthur Augustus Calwell-Member of the House of Representatives 1940-72, Minister 1943-49, ALP Leader 1960-7. Canberra (ACT) Locality-originated from an Aboriginal word, the popular meaning of which is 'meeting place'. Canning (WA) Alfred Wernam Canning-surveyor who pioneered stock roads and rabbit proof fences in Western Australia.
title: Major Systems Details

speaker: History Of Federal Electoral Divisions Mr Young
theText: The answer to the honourableCapricornia (Qld) A district name apparently originating from the fact that the Tropic of Capricorn passes through the area. Casey (Vic). .' . Lord Casey-former Governor General of Australia. Charlton (NSW) . Matthew Charlton-local Member of the House of Representatives 1910-28, ALP Leader 1922-28, Member of New South Wales Legislative Assembly 1903-10. Chifley (NSW) Joseph Benedict Chifley-former Prime Minister. Chisholm (Vic) Caroline Chisholm-nineteenth century social worker and advocate of immigration to New South Wales. Cook (NSW) . James Cook-explorer. Corangamite (Vic) Locality (Lake Corangamite)-orginated from Aboriginal word for 'bitter' (describing salt content of Lake). Corio (Vic) . Locality (Corio Bay)-originated from an Aboriginal word for 'small marsupial'. Cowan (WA) Edith Dirksley Cowan-first woman elected to any Australian Parliament, State or Federal. Cowper (NSW) Sir Charles Cowper-former Premier of New South Wales. Cunningham (NSW). Allan Cunningham-explorer. Curtin (WA) . John Curtin-former Prime Minister. Dawson (Qld). . . Andrew Dawson-Queensland's first Labor Premier; later entered Federal politics as a Senator and was Minister for Defence in the Watson Government. Deakin (Vic) . Sir Alfred Deakin-former Prime Minister. Denison (Tas) . Sir William Thomas Dension-Lt Governor of Tasmania 1847-1855. Dobell (NSW). Sir William Dobell-painter. Dundas (NSW) Locality name. Dunkley (Vic) . Louisa Margaret Dunkley-founder of the Victorian Women's Post and Telegraph Association, campaigner for equal pay. Eden-Monaro (NSW) Locality name,' geographical. Fadden (Qld) Arthur William Fadden-former Prime Minister. Fairfax (Qld) . Ruth Beatrice Fairfax-a founder of the Country Women's Association and its first Queensland President. Farrer (N.S.W.) William James Farrer-wheat breeder and experimentalist. Fisher (Qld) Andrew Fisher-former Prime Minister. Flinders (Vic.). Matthew Flinders-explorer. Forde (Qld) Francis Michael Forde-Prime Minister 1945, Minister 1941-6, Member of the House of Representatives 1922-46, State Member 1917-22, 1953-7, High Commissioner to Canada. Forrest (WA.) Sir John (later Lord) Forrest-Surveyor-General of Western Australia and member of Executive Council. Fowler (N.S.W.) Ljllian Fowler-Member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly 1944-50, first woman mayor in Australia. Franklin (Tas.) Sir John Franklin-Lt-Governor of Tasmania 1837-1843: also an explorer. Fraser (A.C.T.) James Reay Fraser-the Australian Capital Territory's sole representative in the Parliament (as a Member of the House of Representatives) 1951-1970. Fremantle (WA.) Locality name-city named after Charles H. Fremantle who came to Western Australia in 1831 to establish the Port of Fremantle. Gellibrand (Vic.) . John Thomas Gellibrand-explorer. Gilmore (N.S.W.) Dame Mary Gilmore-poet. Gippsland (Vic.) . Locality-named after Governor Gipps. Goldstein (Vic.) . Vida Goldstein-first woman candidate at a national parliamentary election in the British Empire. Grayndler (N.S.W.) . Edward Grayndler-Member of the New South Wales Legislative Council and General Secretary of the Australian Workers Union in the 1920s and 1930s. Greenway (N.S.W.) . Francis Greenway-architect. Grey (S.A.). George Grey-in 1841 became the third Governor of South Australia. Griffith (Qld) . Sir Samuel Walker Griffith-Premier of Queensland and first Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia; Lt-Governor of Queensland 1899 to 1903; remained Chief Justice of the Commonwealth until his retirement in 1919. Groom (Qld) . . Sir Littleton Groom-local Member of the House of Representatives 1900-29, 1931-36; various Ministries. Gwydir (N.S.W.) . Gwydir River. Hawker (S.A.). Charles Alan Seymour Hawker-former Member of the House of Representatives for Wakefield. Henty (Vic.) . Francis Henty-settler in Victoria. Herbert (Qld) . Sir Robert George Wyndham Herbert-first Premier of Queensland. Higgins (Vic.) . Henry Bournes Higgins-former Member of the House of Representatives, Justice of the High Court and Second President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Court. Hindmarsh (S.A.) Sir John Hindmarsh-the first Governor of South Australia. Hinkler (Qld) . Bert Hinkler-aviator whose name is especially linked with Bundaberg. Holt (Vic.) . Harold Edward Holt-former Prime Minister. Hotham (Vic.). Sir Charles Hotham-former Governor of Victoria. Hughes (N.S.W.) . William Morris Hughes-former Prime Minister. Hume (N.S.W.) . Hamilton Hume-explorer. Hunter (N.S.W.) . John Hunter-second Governor of New South Wales. Indi (Vic.) . Aboriginal word for Murray River. Isaacs (Vic.) Sir Isaac Alfred Isaacs-Member of the House of Representatives 1901-06, Justice and later Chief Justice of the High Court, Governor General 1931-36. Jagajaga (Vic.) Three principal Aboriginal elders who signed the treaty with Batman. Kalgoorlie (WA.) Locality name-in addition, name of the mine discovered by Hannan and Flanagan in 1893 from which the town and area took its name. Kennedy (Qld) Edmund Besley Court Kennedy-explorer. Kingsford-Smith (N.S.W.) . Sir Charles Kingsford-Sniith-aviator. Kingston (S.A.) . . Charles Cameron Kingston-Premier of South Australia, elected to the first House of Representatives to represent South Australia in 1901 and in 1903 elected as the first member for the Division of Adelaide. Kooyong (Vic.) Aboriginal name for camp or resting place. Lalor (Vic.). . Peter Lalor-of Eureka Stockade fame. Elected to Victorian -Legislative Council in 1855; then to Legislative Assembly in 1856. La Trobe (Vic.) Charles Joseph La Trobe-Lt-Governor of Victoria. Leichhardt (Qld) . Friedrich Wilhalm Ludwig Leichhardt-explorer. Lilley (Qld). Sir Charles Lilley-Premier and Chief Justice of Queensland. Lindsay (N.S.W.). Norman Lindsay-writer and artist. Lowe (N.S.W.) Robert Lowe, Earl of Sherbrooke-advocated discontinuance of deportation of convicts to New South Wales. Lyne (N.S.W.). Sir William Lyne-former Premier of New South Wales. Lyons (Tas.) . Joseph Aloysius Lyons-former Prime Minister, and Dame Enid Muriel Lyons-Member of the House of Representatives, 1943-51. Macarthur (N.S.W.). John Macarthur-founder oLAustralian merino wool industry. Mackellar (N.S.W.) . Dorothea Mackellar-poet. Macquarie (N.S.W.). Governor Lachlan Macquarie-former Governor of New South Wales. McEwen (Vic.) Sir John McEwen-Prime Minister 1967-68, Minister 1939-41, 194971, Member of the House of Representatives 1934-71 McMillan (Vic.) Angus McMillan-explorer of East Gippsland. McPherson (Qld). This name apparently originated from the McPherson Range which forms the southern boundary of the McPherson electorate. The range was named in 1828 by Allan Cunningham after Major McPherson of His Majesty's 39th Regiment. Makin (S.A.) . Norman Makin-Member of the House of Representatives 1919-46, 1954-63, Speaker 1929-32, Minister. Ambassador to the United States. Mallee (Vic.) . Locality name. Maranoa (Qld) District name taken from the river of that name which passes through the area. The river was named by Thomas Mitchell in 1846. The name is of Aboriginal origin but the authenticity of several meanings suggested is particularly hard to verify. Maribyrnong (Vic.) Locality (Maribyrnong River)-originated from Aboriginal word for 'yam' or 'edible root '. Mayo (S.A.) Helen Mayo-founder of the Mothers' and Babies' Health Association, first woman elected to a University Council in Australia, cofounder of St Anne's College, University of Adelaide. Melbourne (Vic.) . Locality name-city after Viscount Melbourne, Prime Minister of England. Melbourne Ports (Vic.). Locality name. Menzies (Vic.). . Sir Robert Gordon Menzies-Prime Minister 1939-41, 1949-66, Member of the House of Representatives 1934-66. Mitchell (N.S.W.) Thomas Mitchell-explorer and surveyor. Moncrielf (Qld) Gladys Moncrielf-light opera and musical comedy singer. Moore (WA) . George Fletcher Moore-first Advocate-General in Western Australia. Moreton (Qld) A district name originating from the naming by Captain Cook of the bay adjacent to Moreton Island and Stradbroke Island. It was named after the Earl of Morton but due to a spelling error in Hawkworth's edition of Cook's Voyages, the present form of spelling has resulted. Murray (Vic.). . . Locality name from River Murray, which was named after Lt John Murray of the 'Lady Nelson'. Newcastle (N.S.W.) . Locality name. New England. . . Geographical. North Sydney (N.S.W.) Locality name. Northern Territory (N.T.). Geographical. O'Connor (WA.). Charles Yelverton O'Connor-Engineer-in-Chief of the Colony, designed and supervised the construction of the water pipeline from Perth to Kalgoorlie. Oxley (Qld) John Joseph William Molesworth Oxley-explorer. Page (NSW) Sir Earle Christmas Grafton Page, local Member of the House of Representatives 1919-61, Prime Minister 1939, Minister 1923-9, 19349, 1940-1, 1949-56. Parkes (NSW). Sir Henry Parkes-former Premier of New South Wales. Parramatta (NSW) Locality name. Perth (WA) Locality name-after Perth in Scotland. Petrie (Qld) Andrew Petrie-civil engineer, or Thomas Petrie-a Queensland pioneer who arrived in Brisbane in 1837. As a boy he befriended the Aboriginals and later became an authority on their language and customs. He took up cattle country area near Pine River not far from where the town of Petrie now stands. Phillip (NSW). Arthur Phillip-first Governor of Colony of New South Wales. Port Adelaide (SA) Locality name. Prospect (NSW) Locality name including Prospect Reservoir area. Rankin (Qld) . . Dame Annabelle Rankin-first woman Commonwealth Minister with departmental responsibilities, Senator 1946-71, Minister 1966-71, High Commissioner to New Zealand. Reid (NSW) . Sir George Houston Reid-one of the founders of the Constitution and former Prime Minister. Richmond (NSW) Geographical-Richmond River and Richmond Gap between Queensland and New South Wales. Riverina-Darling (NSW) Geographical. Robertson (NSW) Sir John Robertson-former Premier of New South Wales. Ryan (Qld). . . Thomas Joseph Ryan-former Premier of Queensland 1915-1919, resigned to enter Federal politics. St George (NSW) Locality name. Scullin (NSW). James Henry Scullin-former Prime Minister. Shortland (NSW). John Shortland-discoverer of Hunter River estuary. Streeton (Vic) . Sir Arthur Streeton-original member of the Heidelberg School of painting. Stirling (WA) Sir James Stirling-first Governor of Western Australia. Sturt (SA) . Charles Sturt-noted early Australian explorer. Swan (WA) Swan River-originally named Swaanen River by Willem de Vlamingh in 1829. Sydney (NSW) Locality name-city named after Viscount Sydney, Secretary of State for the Colonies in 1787. Tangney (WA) Dame Dorothy Margaret Tangney-first woman Senator. Throsby (NSW) Charles Throsby-local pioneer settler. Wakefield (SA) Edward Gibbon Wakefield-while serving a three years' term of imprisonment, evolved a plan for a systematic, scientific mode of colonisation. The plan formed the basis of settlement in South Australia. Wannon (Vic) . Locality (Wan non River)-named by Major Mitchell, 1836. Warringah (NSW) Locality name. Wentworth (NSW) William Charles Wentworth-explorer. Werriwa (NSW) Aboriginal name for Lake George, which was located in the electorate in 1901. Wide Bay (Qld) District name-the Wide Bay district takes its name from the bay named by Captain Cook on 18 May 1770. Wills (Vic). . William John Wills-explorer.
